edge: The film is a standalone sequel to Space Jam (1996).
The film is a live-action/animated sports comedy film produced by Warner Animation Group, Proximity Media, and The SpringHill Company.
James stars as a fictional version of himself in the film.
The film features the Looney Tunes characters, including Jeff Bergman, Eric Bauza, and Zendaya.
The film follows James's mission in a Warner Bros.-themed virtual multiverse.
The film pits James against the rogue artificial intelligence's avatars.
Cheadle stars in live-action roles in the film, along with Khris Davis, Sonequa Martin-Green, and Cedric Joe.
Discussions for a Space Jam successor began following its release.

The context mentions that the concept art for the film was created by animation director Devin Crane, who also worked on HBO Max's Looney Tunes Cartoons. This suggests a relationship between the film and the cartoon series.

The context states that Elmer Fudd, a popular Looney Tunes character, will be allowed to appear with his trademark guns in the film. This indicates a connection between Elmer Fudd and the Looney Tunes universe, as depicted in HBO Max's Looney Tunes Cartoons.
Like Elmer Fudd, Yosemite Sam will also appear with his gun in the film. This highlights a relationship between Yosemite Sam and Looney Tunes Cartoons.

The context mentions that in HBO Max's Looney Tunes Cartoons, a temporary ban was enacted against depicting firearms due to the mass shootings and gun violence in the US. This shows a connection between the cartoon series and the larger Looney Tunes universe.
In March 2020, photos taken on set and a brief recording of the wrap party were leaked online, revealing that the film would feature characters from other Warner-owned properties.
LeBron had an injury he suffered during production
The filmmakers had a rigorous schedule and shot 14 hours a day.
Both visual effects and computer animation for the Looney Tunes characters were provided by Lucasfilm's visual effects division, Industrial Light & Magic (ILM).
The 2D animation was provided by Company 3 Animation.
Additional CGI effects were also provided by Luma and Cinesite, who previously provided them in the first Space Jam.

While the 2D animation was provided by Company 3 Animation, and Tonic DNA, who previously worked with Warner Brothers on Looney Tunes Cartoons, this is the second collaboration with the Looney Tunes in using ILM for visual effects since Who Framed Roger Rabbit (1988).

The film incorporates both traditional and CG animation, making it the first film from Warner Animation Group to incorporate traditional animation that was for the most part tradigitally created with Toon Boom's Harmony software.
Dan Haskett, who has worked on the Looney Tunes since 1979, was hired to work in the animation department as well.
Matt Williames, who had not worked with Warner Bros. Since Looney Tunes: Back in Action, started doing animation for the film in August of the same year.
In January 2020, veteran Walt Disney Animation Studios animators Mark Henn, Tony Bancroft, and the latter's brother Tom were hired by Warner Animation Group to work on the film.
In January 2020, veteran Walt Disney Animation Studios animators Mark Henn, Tony Bancroft, and the latter's brother Tom were hired by Warner Animation Group to work on the film.
Brandt was hired back on to the project as animation director while Cervone was also hired back on to work in the film's animation department.

Director Malcolm D. Lee also learned a lot of experience working on animation from Spike Brandt, like harkening the Looney Tunes' designs back to the ones he remembered, and their animated expressions.
Ole Loken, who worked extensively on animation hit Klaus, announced that he would serve as an animator on the film.

In its opening weekend, Space Jam: A New Legacy was streamed by 2.1 million U.S. Households, one of the best totals for its AB Warner Bros. Day-in-date release.
By the end of its first 30 days, Space Jam: A New Legacy was watched in over 4.2 million U.S. Households.
In the United States and Canada, Space Jam: A New Legacy grossed $70.6 million.
In other territories, Space Jam: A New Legacy grossed $93.1 million.
Overall, Space Jam: A New Legacy grossed $163.7 million worldwide.
In its opening weekend, Space Jam: A New Legacy earned $31.1 million from 3,965 theaters.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, Space Jam: A New Legacy had the second highest opening weekend for a Warner Bros. Film after Godzilla vs. Kong with $31.6 million.
In its second weekend, Space Jam: A New Legacy earnings dropped by 69% to $9.5 million.
Space Jam: A New Legacy earned another $4.2 million on its third weekend.

The majority of critical reviews for Space Jam: A New Legacy targeted its 'lack of fun humor and earnest light-heartedness, overt promotion of Warner Bros. property, disappointment with celebrity and NBA roles, and the long two-hour runtime compared to [the first] Space Jam's 87 minutes'
As of [insert date], Space Jam: A New Legacy holds an approval rating of 25% based on 229 reviews with an average rating of 4.4/10 on Rotten Tomatoes.
As of [insert date], Space Jam: A New Legacy scored 36 out of 100 based on 46 critics on Metacritic, indicating 'generally unfavorable reviews'.
Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave Space Jam: A New Legacy an average grade of 'A−' on an A+ to F scale, the same as the first film.
78% of filmgoers gave Space Jam: A New Legacy a positive score, with 58% saying they would definitely recommend it as reported by PostTrak.
Fell just short of asking audiences point blank to subscribe to HBO Max, ultimately a devoid-of-laughs experience that shoots far wide of the mark.
A New Legacy is a sequel/tribute to the original Space Jam.
According to Hagan Osborne of FilmInk, what is most thrilling about A New Legacy is the liveliness of the worlds created.
According to Amy Nicholson of Variety, Space Jam: A New Legacy is chaotic and rainbow sprinkle-colored nonsense that holds together as a movie.
According to Kristen Page-Kirby of The Washington Post, there's no real reason for Space Jam: A New Legacy to exist, but now that it does, there's no reason to wish that it didn't.
According to Double Toasted (Korey Coleman and Martin Thomas), one positive aspect of Space Jam: A New Legacy is the creative use of the characters.
According to Double Toasted (Korey Coleman and Martin Thomas), another positive aspect of Space Jam: A New Legacy is the acting.
According to Double Toasted (Korey Coleman and Martin Thomas), one negative aspect of Space Jam: A New Legacy is the presence of outdated references.
According to Keith Hawkes of Parent Previews, there is an issue with Space Jam: A New Legacy cashing in on nostalgia for a classic franchise.
Brian Lowry of CNN referred to the first Space Jam as ' hardly a classic ', which should temper expectations for this sequel.
Simran Hans of The Guardian described the sequel as 'a marketing-driven exercise' that sometimes plays like a subpar version of the original.
Simran Hans of The Guardian also noted that the sequel 'seems to earnestly revel in the recyclable potential' of Warner Bros.' intellectual property.
The sequel 'insert[s] Lola Bunny (Zendaya; wasted) into the world of Wonder Woman' during its elastic, mile-a-minute animated sequences.
Simran Hans of The Guardian noted that the sequel also 'sent Tweety and Granny into The Matrix' during its animated sequences.
